0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• do not inject systemically as that can lead to extensive intravascular clotting and death
  • Control of hemorrhage: apply up to 10 mL TOPICALLY on the surface of the bleeding tissue with or without an Absorbable Gelatin Sponge, USP; amount required depends upon the area of tissue being treated and the method of application

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• do not inject systemically as that can lead to extensive intravascular clotting and death
  • Control of hemorrhage: apply up to 10 mL TOPICALLY on the surface of the bleeding tissue with or without an Absorbable Gelatin Sponge, USP; amount required depends upon the area of tissue being treated and the method of application

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Control of hemorrhage
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Peptic ulcer with hemorrhage

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis or severe systemic reaction to human blood products
  • arterial bleeding, severe or brisk
  • direct circulatory injection; extensive intravascular clotting and even death may occur

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• human plasma-derived product; theoretical risk of infectious disease transmittal including viruses and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • systemic absorption; potential for thrombosis
  • report all drug-induced infections to Ethicon Customer Support Center 877-384-4266

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Thrombin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (0.7%)
  • Hematologic:International normalized ratio, Increased (2.6%), Lymphocyte count abnormal, Decreased (2.6%), Neutrophil count abnormal, Increased (2%), Partial thromboplastin time increased (2.6%), Prothrombin time increased (2.6%)
Serious
Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (rare)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Thrombin is a protein substance that immediately clots the fibrinogen of the blood directly without the aid of a physiological agent. It is a highly specific protease that convert fibrinogen into fibrin. Thrombin, human is made from pooled human plasma.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    do not inject; for topical application only
  • Topical
    • thaw prior to use in one of 3 ways: at 2 to 8 degrees C in refrigerator, vials thaw within 1 day; at 20 to 25 degrees C (room temperature), vials thaw within 1 hour; at 37 degrees C, 2-mL and 5-mL vials only may be thawed for 10 min MAX (temperature should NOT exceed 37 degrees C)
    • (using human thrombin alone) sponge or suction target area free of blood before application, do not wipe; flood surface with human thrombin using sterile syringe with small gauge needle; do not sponge clot after administration
    • (using human thrombin with an Absorbable Gelatin Sponge, USP) transfer human thrombin to a sterile container and immerse sponge; vigorously knead sponge with moistened, gloved fingers until all air is expelled; using moderate pressure, hold sponge in place on target surface with gauze or cotton pledget until hemostasis is achieved

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• clinical evidence of hemostasis thrombosis and any signs of abnormalities in hemostasis
  • thrombosis and any signs of abnormalities in hemostasis
  • transmittal infectious disease, including viruses and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a remote risk of transmitting infectious agents including Hepatitis A and Parvovirus B19. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare professional.
  • This drug may cause anaphylactic reactions.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of thrombosis. Drug may increase risk of thrombosis if absorbed systemically.
